intro: Salvia galeata, commonly known as woodland sage, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, which is characterized by square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, lance-shaped leaves with a slightly hairy surface. Its flowers are small, tubular, and typically pink or purple, arranged in whorled clusters at the ends of the stems. Salvia galeata thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in woodlands and streamside habitats.
